title: When will British Airways resume commercial flights to mainland China?
preds: Incremental update. Less than 48 hours to go.
There are still no scheduled flights.
There are still no scheduled flights.
as noted previously in the comments, there are no flight schedules and its too late to have a flight before the deadline.
Only a week left and there are still no scheduled flights.

Initial forecast. Joining late (6/23/2020).
Current Crowd forecast is Not before 1 July 2020 - 98%.
International air travel is still restricted.  Reports of new breakouts in China.  BA flying 21 cargo flights per week from China to UK. Only one week left in forecast.

No signals pointing toward a restart of flights to China. Even if they were opening for flights to China I would expect it to be at least a week from the announcement to when they actually start flying. So putting everything in one basket now.

HT to @Ryan-Larkin for the note on the lounge art. Virgin is pushing out their flights to China until Aug from July [1]. I checked ba.com and was unable to book a flight to either Beijing or Shanghai through the end of the month [2]. All into the last bucket. [1] https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2020/06/22/virgin-atlantic-delays-restart-of-orlando-flights-amid-floridas-covid-19-spike/
[2] ba.com

Only Delta is resuming flights to China before July 2020, and those seem to be only to Shanghai. As of today, there is only 9 days left before July, and the CAAC has repeatedly denied requests from United Airlines to resume commercial passenger flights to China. There s however, the small possibility that something crazy and out of the blue drastically changes.
I don't see enough pressure from business or public to open this route before 1 July.
Moving everything to the 'Not before 1st July 2020' bucket.

We are now 10 days away from July 1st and nowhere close to seeing a flight to mainland China.  IN fact there are pending strikes from some of the remaining coworkers even if the company does re-open.  https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/11890329/british-airways-strikes-flies-passengers-fear/
 Additionally, there's a resurgence of COVID-19 in China causing many carriers to cancel existing flights there.   https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/17/asia/beijing-flight-cancellation-intl-hnk/index.html
To add insult to injury they are also being forced to sell their famous lounge art.https://thepointsguy.com/news/british-airways-selling-art-lounges/

With the potential of 2nd wave of COVID-19 surging again in the 2nd half of this year, and that we have seen the beginning of that with the recent Beijing and the Northeastern China, Also, IAG, owner of British Airway had already announced they plan to resume flights in July at the earliest.
given current resurgence in infection rates in Main Land China travel restrictions will be extended
With a new cluster outbreak in Beijing, Any new flights are unlikely. Both countries will not push for it.

No signals flights will resume soon. Outbreak, although small, in China. More than half of June passed. 
For those reasons I'm readjusting a bit to Not before 1 July.
new outbreaks in China make this unlikely

Gan, N. (2020). China's new coronavirus outbreak sees Beijing adopt 'wartime' measures as capital races to contain spread. CNN. World. Asia. June 15, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/15/asia/coronavirus-beijing-outbreak-intl-hnk/index.html (CNN) Beijing is reintroducing strict lockdown measures and rolling out mass testing after a fresh cluster of novel coronavirus cases emerged from the city's largest wholesale food market, sparking fears of a resurgence of the deadly outbreak. The Chinese capital reported 36 new Covid-19 cases on Monday, bringing the total number to 79 since a locally transmitted infection was reported on June 12 for the first time in nearly two months, according to the National Health Commission. The cases are linked to Xinfadi market in the southwest of the city, which supplies most of the capital's fresh fruit and vegetables. The market, which also sells meat and seafood, has been shut down since Saturday.
Given current resurgence of COVID 19 cases in China it is highly unlikely that international travel will be eased or increased
There are still no scheduled flights.
Flights are beginning to open but only for certain class seats.
China doesn't like the case count in UK
China is going to explode with pandemic
mainland china has a new outbreak and will shut borders
We’re in mid June and can’t find any evidence there are currently flights, so changed forecast to 100% not before July.
There are still no scheduled flights.
I think I know the answer.

Well it's one week closer to July 1st and all signs point to no flights.  Last week an article came out with some potential hints on opening up flights again.  This week I've searched multiple travel agencies and no flights to China are offered.  That combined with the law suit, firing 12,000 employees, and attempting to sell art to gain back some revenue, point to no flights to China.
Today is June 12!! Covid-19 is still up and alive in UK!
Time's up. Place your bets. Only one option left.

Flights into China may resume in June since China has banned US airliners from entering the country. British and European carriers may profit from American/international travel. https://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-airlines-to-resume-flights-to-china-us-155585 But the optics of travel into China still pose considerable hurdles, coupled with the administrative mess of quarantine on travel. My base rate for such predictions would be an emphatic 'no' to reopening in a time span of three weeks (1st July - 12th June ~ 3 wks), thus my prediction is skewed towards 'Not Before July 2020'.
Lack of demand for flights. UK quarantine regulations. "Optics" of flying to China at this time.
The virus is moving fast and will circle back by then.
china is not letting flights in yet from America
Revising my earlier prediction given the current state of international airline travel. I was expecting at least once a week flights to start in June, but it seems it will be pushed out to July.

As others have noted, the UK has a 14-day quarantine period for international arrivals into the UK, that is going to last for at least the next 3 weeks (to be reviewed at that point) [1]. China is also issuing rules and fines around flights that arrive with a COVID-positive passenger [2]. Virgin is now saying flights to international destinations (including China) won't be until July [3].  There may be a slim-chance of someone starting up before the end of this month, but with the hoops and fines, I expect it is unlikely. [1] https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2020/06/07/travel-updates-quarantine-measure-full-loopholes-say-critics/
[2] https://www.forbes.com/sites/willhorton1/2020/06/04/airlines-will-be-punished-if-passengers-have-covid-19-under-chinas-new-system-for-flight-and-travel-restrictions/#6b0764b5e200
[3] https://www.ch-aviation.com/portal/news/91637-uks-virgin-atlantic-set-to-resume-intl-passenger-flights
Ok. Tried to book flight from LHR in June to various Beijing airports but no can do.
Turmoil in UK skies over flights and quarantine will perhaps stall flights a little longer.

With five days to go, and additional legal disruptions, I'm now very skeptical of the Business Traveller article. PR now seems to be claiming an (attempted) return to most service in July[1]. [1] https://thepointsguy.com/news/ba-flights-july/

Do indirect flights count where one leg is covered by another carrier? For example BA has flights to PVG currently but it goes through Hong Kong and the flight from Hong Kong to Beijing is being serviced by Hong Kong Airlines but the flight can be booked through the BA website. If this counts then 100% would be between 1 June and 30 June. However if BA has to operate all the legs then I would say not before July 1, 2020.
I'll  nudge a little for a June first flight, but only for the next two weeks, then back to 100.

This was my first week with a major drop due to this article by Business Traveller.  It would have been even more if the UK government hadn't instituted the 14 day quarantine (Which BA is contemplating suing them for).   According to Routes Online, British Airways is planning the following long-haul operations in June.
(NB:  this was before the announcement of a proposed 14-day quarantine the UK Government is said to be planning. We will update this section as and when more details are revealed).
London Heathrow – Boston 1 daily 787-8
London Heathrow – Chicago O’Hare 1 daily 787-9
London Heathrow – Delhi 1 daily 787-8
London Heathrow – Hong Kong 6 weekly 777-300ER
London Heathrow – Johannesburg 1 daily 777-300ER
London Heathrow – Lagos 787-9 operates alternating days
London Heathrow – Los Angeles 1 daily 787-9
London Heathrow – Montreal 1 daily 787-8
London Heathrow – Mumbai 787-9 operates alternating days
London Heathrow – New York JFK 2 daily 747-400/777-200ER
London Heathrow – San Francisco 1 daily 787-8
London Heathrow – Sao Paulo Guarulhos 1 daily 777-300ER
London Heathrow – Singapore 777-200ER operates alternating days
London Heathrow – Tel Aviv 1 daily A350-1000XWB
London Heathrow – Tokyo Haneda 787-9 operates on alternating days
London Heathrow – Toronto 1 daily 787-8
London Heathrow – Washington Dulles 1 daily A350-1000XWB
BA also currently lists London Heathrow – Beijing Daxing (from 14JUN20) and London Heathrow – Shanghai Pu Dong schedule for June 2020, however only the following booking class open for reservation: A / C / E / B. Both routes scheduled as alternating days service.
https://www.businesstraveller.com/features/airlines-planning-to-resume-some-flights-in-june/
No change in communication from BA. 3.5 weeks to schedule and commence flights is not impossible but little incentive for UK.

Europe has just now started to open borders slowly
China perceived the prolonged Covid-19 spread mostly an "imported" problem and will have a hard time opening borders sooner rather than later
UK is struggling to keep the outbreak under control and real effect take about 2 weeks to show results
UK/HK/CH relations are really tense. If UK opens borders to HK Chinese, this will put an extra strain on the matter

Given that I'm looking at this at the beginning of June, there's not a lot of time left for flights to restart with no warning. My prior is that it's quite unlikely flights will start up again that quickly, in the 5-10% range. The fact that there are no flights scheduled [0] and that a BA rep on Twitter claimed (in May) that the first flights will be in August [1] pushes it to the lower end of that range. The only things pushing the probability up are are an (admittedly, more recent) report from Business Traveller Asia Pacific that claims BA will resume flights June 14th [2] and the fact that other carriers, namely Lufthansa, have resumed Europe-Beijing flights[3] and might apply some competitive pressure.  [0] https://www.britishairways.com/travel/booking/public/en_au/#/flightList?origin=LHR&destination=BJS&outboundDate=2020-06-20&adultCount=1&youngAdultCount=0&childCount=0&infantCount=0&cabin=M&ticketFlexibility=LOWEST&journeyType=OWFLT
[1] https://twitter.com/British_Airways/status/1265711460224729089
[2] https://www.businesstraveller.com/features/airlines-planning-to-resume-some-flights-in-june/
[3] https://www.lufthansa.com/gb/en/flights/city/beijing
No flights available on BA website - Shanghai as of July

https://www.businesstraveller.com/features/airlines-planning-to-resume-some-flights-in-june/ (thanks to @fisherdbus)
https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/05/28/business/china-overseas-flights/#.XtdFHjozY2w We could see at least some flight activity resume in June. 
From BAs perspective, China is relatively safe (ATM) and the routes would see demand. 
The Chinese are also okay with flights resuming. So changing:
1 June - 30 June (increased to 65% from 5%)
Not before 1st July (decreased from 95% to 35%)

On 29 May 2020, Lufthansa brought about 200 German expatriate managers (and some other nationalities) working in China back to Tianjin Airport (near Peking) on a charter flight. A second flight is said to be scheduled for tomorrow 03 June 2020 to Shanghai. They will be able to return to work after spending a 14-day-quarantine in a hotel. I wonder if this type of flight is covered in the question, as it is of commercial background, but not in the regular flight plan. BA might follow this example soon, as the economic interests of British multinationals and Britons working in China are affected as well and they will want to resume their business rather sooner than later, which seems to be possible by special permit.

China is allowing flights from UK
https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/05/28/business/china-overseas-flights/#.XtEHSTpKg2w BA was planning on having flights to Shanghai in June 2020. However not available currently on website
https://www.businesstraveller.com/features/airlines-planning-to-resume-some-flights-in-june/ So within possibility but as June is fast approaching and they still don't have anything booked it's unlikely they are going to set up flights with very short notice.

came across some messages I didn't understand well. "BA also currently lists London Heathrow – Beijing Daxing (from 14JUN20) and London Heathrow – Shanghai Pu Dong schedule for June 2020, however only the following booking class open for reservation: A / C / E / B. Both routes scheduled as alternating days service." Then I just asked them directly: "our schedule is still changing due to the ongoing situation. Currently, the first direct flights operating to Beijing is on 01 August" Always had 100%. >1july, gonna give 1%  now to the other range.

Google flights is no longer showing tickets available in June or July for London to Shanghai or London to Beijing, though there are daily flights starting August first. The Chinese travel advisory remains in place, and I don't see it as likely that it will be lifted before July.
reconfirming existing belief - UK opening up will lead to increase in infections, and however small, will prevent China from opening up flights
Strained UK-China relations.  New outbreaks in NE China.
Tickets aren’t available yet. Could be a symbolic reopening flight at short notice.
Can’t book direct flight anymore, need to go via HK until august 1st. But things evolve fast, so I leave some

British Airways has said they hope to resume travel at 50% by July. I assume BA will begin by resuming flights within in Europe. Therefore it seem unlikely to me at this moment BA will arrange flights to China before July.

Has anyone requested clarification and/or resolution with respect to the ongoing BA flights from London to Shanghai? I understand that they are cargo-only, but would interpret that as a “commercial flight,” such that this would be resolved at this point. Please relieve me of this very awkward straddle on my forecast... https://flightaware.com/live/flight/BAW161

more talk of flights starting again June after new protocols from CAA. However is China too politically sensitive a destination to fly to in the early days plus the quarantee rules will deter travellers. BA might want to make a defiant point though so perhaps a slight increase in likelyhood.
Runway too short to course correct for Airlines - also, statistics still not promising

Past May 1st at this point, so that has to be 0% and there are no flights available for purchase during May, so also going 0% on that. There are flights available in June through British airways, but you have to switch airlines in say Germany before flying to China.  It is not until the 2nd week of July that there are direct flights from London to Beijing available. While it seems possible they will move things up before July 1, I would imagine they don't add a lot of new flights on dates where ones are not scheduled.
It looks like there is movement in Europe pointing to July. https://nbcmontana.com/news/coronavirus/more-european-flights-to-resume-in-july-but-demand-seen-low

Regardless of the UK advisory, which may or may not be lifted in June, I think it is the Chinese restriction on entrance for foreign nationals that will make this last into July. I've read elsewhere that China is becoming more closed off to foreigners, so I don't think they will be easing restrictions any time soon, especially given the state of the pandemic in Europe and the US.  Official Government Advisory:
https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/wjbxw/t1761867.shtml Info From China Briefing (website): 
"Since March 28, the country’s borders are closed to almost all foreigners and only about 20 international flights can land in its soil each day."  Most of the international travel (if not all) appears to be from within Asia.  The 3% June possibility hinges on approval of travel based on screening that includes testing before boarding flights. I think this will happen eventually, but likely not before July 1 for the UK. This protocol will most likely start, and may have already begun, with travel from other Asian countries with less infection before an agreement is in place with the UK. 
https://www.china-briefing.com/news/chinas-travel-restrictions-due-to-covid-19-an-explainer/
Prediction of UK quarantine laws make international flights unlikely. Still a chance that they will be lifted before the very end of June. Though unlikely.
Booking a flight is not the same as actually taking one. My imaginary short business trip to Shanghai would then require me to quarantine in the UK upon my return. I think I'll use FaceTime instead.

I'm tempted to change this, but there are signs of the world starting to open up again. 
China settling into a new-normal and the worst-hit countries in Europe are cautiously opening their beaches and restaurants.  
I cannot find any correspondence about what BA is planning, but in looking at their bookings, they are accepting bookings in June, at nearly twice the cost that it'll be in July. 
Flights will most probably start in June.
Quarantine etc still in place so prospects of a June resumption receded.
I was deadly wrong with this one. I followed a wrong leader I’m afraid.

British airways had planned to resume half of flights from July, however followign government guidance in the UK of a 14 day quarantine for anyone returning, this looks less likely to occur, and BA are currently providing a refund option for people with flights booked until the 31 July, making flights prior to this date highly unlikely.

Based on the very rough forecasting made availble at https://tinyurl.com/yd98b7wg.
Even when adjusting to take account for underreported correction between x1.0 and x5.0,  the last infectious person is due between 03/07 - 10/09 (1 sigma confidence region from the simulation expanded to adjust to unknowns not taken into account by the simulation itself). This is already very rough and ready. Using @chwang SARS extrapolation, it should take between 5-7 weeks after the last case for flights to resume. Take away the 14 days from the last infectious person and you get 24/07 - 05/10 68% uncertainty range for reopening. This is huge and gives a *16% probability to reopening before 24/07*.  This translates to [0%, 1%, 5%, 94%] rounded.  However, given the statement by IAG's chief executive (https://www.bbc.com/news/business-52570936) "Meaningful service not before 1st July", I will adjust the figures. But BA have extended before so the adjustment will be skewed in favour of continuing not to fly: [0%, 0%, 2%, 98%].
Sounds like IAG are pushing back their target for even 50% of the schedule to be flown. With the 2 week quarantine, I think it is very unlikely there will be flights to China being brought back in.

Unlikely to commence before July
1. BA plans relaunch in July (while some agility might be possible, moth-balling  these aircraft is expected to be rather arduous - so without substantial swings in improvement the current plan holds)
2. With UK in current disarray with Contagion under only moderate levels of containment, China will be unlikely to open up to UK travelers https://www.gazetteandherald.co.uk/news/national/uk_today/18433386.british-airways-plans-relaunch-some-flights-july---bosses-said/

I guess Q2 is when we can see routes being reactivated. So 95% chance for past 1st July. https://www.gazetteandherald.co.uk/news/national/uk_today/18433386.british-airways-plans-relaunch-some-flights-july---bosses-said/
https://www.forbes.com/sites/willhorton1/2020/05/10/european-airlines-resume-flights-for-summer-travel-at-different-paces-but-british-airwaysiag-air-france-klm-and-lufthansa-may-converge/#3537da861b57
Decrease a bit, but som BA flights to Hong Kong are active (as per Flightradar24). Not very clear how HK is different from mainland China as far as UK-China covid relationships are concerned.
BA is hedging, even though you can book a flight to Shanghai on their website in June, not clear it will actually fly.
The increase in any flights, let alone to China, is looking increasingly unlikely [1]. HT @Gjlewis [1] https://www.bbc.com/news/business-52570936

BA are talking about resumming a 50% service from July 2020. that may mean one or two flights before then but even if they do, locations are unknown. USA is still in lockdown but China opening up so a small possibility exists they will fly to China but overwhelmingly unlikely.

Willie Walsh, IAG's chief executive, said: "We are planning for a meaningful return to service in July 2020 at the earliest, depending on the easing of lockdowns and travel restrictions around the world." (https://www.bbc.com/news/business-52570936) 'Meaningful' return to service doesn't strictly preclude some commercial flights before this time, but looks fairly unlikely.

The drive for an economic restart will push for the earliest opening possible, even though citizens may be hesitant to take flights even after restrictions are lifted. However, since some countries that BA operates in are in recovery mode with declining infection rates, the airline may pick specific airports in those low risk countries to resume flights.

Restarting commercial flights is important from an economic point of view. I Think this forecast should cover further dates.  I think that there are few chances of opening before July 1st. But good unexpected news and the pressure of the economy could change the outlook very quickly.

BA let me book a flight to Shanghai on May 31 for 455 pounds sterling from London. Not clear if the May 31 flight will occur, but they are booking thru June now. This may continue to be a fluid situation, so I'll split the difference.

I can't find any info on what BA's doing WRT flights to China. The only clue I have is that I can book flights in June, but not in May. Which does not mean they're not going to fly... frustrating.  
Does anyone have any info?

Not a full scale opening, but would expect a few flights in June, surely a big route for BA business travel, and upgraded seats (which airlines will need to be selling to make any money!) China isn't a hotspot comparatively anymore, so will probably be a political stance if nothing continues.
Lockdown in UK is unlikely to end much before end of May. Question is whether before end of June.

This question should be closed. See

London to Shanghai 
Service Type:- Normal Passenger. 
Records in Flightradar24 show this service to mainland China was resumed before 1st of May.

They are currently carrying PPE cargo in the seats of planes [1]. BA is also reducing its workforce [2]. With only a "handfull" of flights in total, let alone to China, it seems unlikely there will be a change in May, and certainly likely to stay grounded beyond that point. I'll lighten up a little and think positive on airlines resuming some operations. But only a little. BA cannot afford to fly empty seats, but maintaining social distancing on these long flights requires it.

I believe it's highly probable that B.A. would prefer to lose money through grounded planes than put its staff at in danger and risk reputational damage. Even with a slowing of cases, this is based up the John Hopkins data, but can the reporting from China be trusted?  I don't feel we will have a good enough of idea for a good couple of months.

Currently new cases in UK are on the decline (fewer case each subsequent day ).  Daily new cases  for past week are between 1.002 and .861 x # cases reported the day before. Italy has been in that range for 32 days. Italy is still hovering just below 1 x previous days new cases. I expect the Chinese will not permit flights until that number is much closer to .005. This may be affected by expanded testing in UK. Or China may have UK citizens remain in isolation upon arrival for a set period of time. It seems unlikely all this will happen in next 2 months.
FT — British Airways to cut 12,000 jobs as aviation outlook darkens https://www.ft.com/content/8529c498-fbf1-4eca-a468-9b26b4ec7a97 No word on resuming flights to mainland China.

Airlines are keen to resume business as soon as possible and are looking to employ social distancing on flights where possible, along with additional measures.  The demand for flights to China in the near future is unlikely to be high and is unlikely to prove financially profitable. The FCO advice is still advise against all but essential travel to China, with Wuhan being advise against all travel, further reducing the likelihood of an earlier resumption in service.
Shorter more profitable flights have not resumed. It is likely that short haul flights would resume before flights to China.

Hard one to have any science around. Based on an IAG press release it seems they are not going to think about ramping up the schedule again before June and we in the UK may just be coming out of the most severe elements of the lockdown by the end of May. So if there is nothing major that changes, it feels like BA may try to trying to ramp up a schedule by early June, but I doubt they start with BA, and they probably play that out based on whether they get travel on less "risky" routes. Not seeing a big push for business or pleasure travel from what I see in media or talking to people. So it feels like it is something like Prob things do not get worse x Prob BA will even try running more flights in June on that basis x Prob they will get traction on more normal parts of the schedule in June . The first and second links may be a bit above 50%, but the last one seems to me likely to be a lot below
Strong commercial incentive, likelihood of ability to put reliable safety measures in place, political will and uncertainty over the UK situation strongest factors to result in further delay.

May 1st is gone, same as <Jun1 - While China is clearing up, the UK seems not in control of the situation. With PRC media having stoked up fears for foreigners, it will take a while before normal procedures commence (only pressure to resume is Business & Trade for China)
The flight operation will depend on whether China will be ready to accept these flights due to the risk from second wave. Therefore, even the chances of operations resuming after July 2020 is slim.
Currently booking 5/31 but wouldn't be surprised to see it pushed back again.

I am fairly confident that the UK will have no impetus (due to the health and political situation) to resume flight for many months. I cannot see this realistically happening until late in the Fall or towards the New Year

Newspaper reporting that restrictions will start to be lifted in the UK in the second half of May.  Question is whether China will accept UK passengers without quarantine. Given both UK and China are keen to rebuild economy, there is a scenario that sees international flights permitted.
Uk will exit lockdown in early mid-May. China is already relaxing quarantine restrictions.

China looking to project the start of normality plus pressure on UK airlines to start to get business moving leads to slight increase in earlier return but with lockdown until at least May in UK then phased unlocking, flights from UK airports still seem very unlikely before end May

China looking to project the start of normality plus pressure on UK airlines to start to get business moving leads to slight increase in earlier return but with lockdown until at least May in UK then phased unlocking, flights from UK airports still seem very unlikely before end May
Time passes, and we will ultimately need to get back to international travel for economic reasons
Just a feeling after Boris barely survived the virus and afterwards called the NHS "invincible". Feels like desperation...
Taking into consideration the time China took to recover + the time GB took to get sick + GB‘s recovery + security margin
Epidemic within UK changes dynamics a lot. Quarantine on Both ends, creates passenger barrier. If people perceive that China is under-reporting, ban will lasr longer.
I think it’s unlikely significant demand will be in place and that inline with PR concerns will push this out to late summer

Chinese cities are now lifting quarantine restrictions. If there is not a second breakout, then Chinese likely to start lifting restrictions on foreigners. There would likely need to be lifting of restrictions in the uk, which won’t happen for at least 3 weeks.
Covid is just hitting the UK, China is closing travel from countries with high Covid; will take at least 2 months to determine if travel from UK is feasible.

There are two drivers. One is  Beijing’s willingness to accept foreign visitors without quarantine. The other is the need to kickstart the economy.  Blogs/ newspapers indicate Beijing is relaxing lockdown. If UK follows same trajectory, then early relaxing will be 4 to 6 weeks’ time (end of May).  Question is when mutual sufficient confidence returns. Guessing no more than a month.  Just needs one route to open and both govts keen for economic kick-start.

IAG, which owns British Airways, Iberia and Aer Lingus, has canceled all flights to and from Italy until at least April 4 but will continue to work with authorities to determine a safe time to restart travel. Flights to China continue to be suspended until April 18. BA made the decision to pull all flights to and from Beijing and Shanghai until April 17, 2020. The airline has also reduced its schedule to Hong Kong, merging two daily flights into one. The head of British Airways said coronavirus was causing an unprecedented crisis, warning that aircraft would be parked like never before and staff laid off, in a hard-hitting staff message to address "the worsening situation". "It is a crisis of global proportions like no other we have known," BA Chief Executive Alex Cruz told staff. "Please do not underestimate the seriousness of this for our company." The message headlined "the survival of British Airways", comes as airlines across the world cancel flights and cut costs to counter the plunging demand and U.S. travel restrictions on European passengers. As a result, he said that jobs would be lost "perhaps for a short period, perhaps longer-term" and that the company was in discussions with trade unions. Aircraft would be grounded in a way that the airline has never had to do before.
--------------------
British Airways scraps its dividend and furloughs over 30,000 staff on 80% pay in a desperate bid to survive the worst crisis in its history
-------------------
COMMENTS: However, this question is not just about whether or not BA will want to resume flights, but more whether BA can resume flights. Besides the financial issues reported above, the reduction of personnel may induce BA to make careful decisions about their routes too. However, the main issue I'm afraid will be whether BA will be authorized to resume flights. As of today the UK has about 40K infected people and growing. China still has some more cases, it is not completely under control.

I compare the date of deleted flights with the date of massive spreading news about coronavirus. I try to evaluate the delay in response: if t0 or t1, t2, and so on. I apply the same time span that I'll call "reaction time".
Then I create a 4x4 matrix where I set values for earning/cost. Flying (earning) vs possible infections (cost) and no infections (earning) vs no flights (cost). The combo where direct and indirect economic losses are smaller gives me an idea when it's time to react. Plus, in China more people will be immune and danger may come from other countries.

Based on 2003 SARS response, travel restrictions were not lifted until no new reported cases x 3 incubation periods. In this case, this appears to be 14 days. Therefore, the travel ban will not be lifted until 6 weeks after the last new case in China. To put this in perspective, WHO placed China on a travel ban for 4 months during the SARS epidemic (3/29/03 - 7/3/03). COVID seems larger but less lethal. China is still reporting new cases, though at a much lower rate (46 yesterday). There is a very small chance they could eliminate all new spread in the next 2 weeks (to qualify for May 1 deadline). Alternatively, if the disease becomes widespread, the WHO might downgrade their recommendation and airlines may resume flights but with recommendation that high risk people (elderly, chronic diseases, immunosuppressed) avoid travel.
Only a hunch, but with a low rating on the first option due to the worsening current situation. With a heavy advantage to the final option due to its longer period

My understanding is that British Airways only has commercial flights to two locations in mainland China: Beijing and Shanghai [1].  As of yesterday, their summary on the situation regarding cancellation of flights to these two locations is as follows: "Following the Foreign Office’s continued advice against all but essential travel to mainland China, we have cancelled our flights to and from Beijing and Shanghai until 19 April 2020. This situation will remain under review and we will continue to provide regular updates" [2]. The latest WHO Situation Report [3] shows that there remain new cases in Beijing province but not Shanghai province - specifically, there are 3 new confirmed cases in Beijing and 0 in Shanghai. However, there are also 26 suspected cases in Beijing and 48 in Shanghai - so more confirmed cases in the coming days seems likely. Thus, it seems likely that more cancellations will occur - it seems probable, for instance, that there will be another 15-20 day extension of the cancellation period.  Beyond that, it is extremely difficult to ascertain how the epidemic in mainland China will play out - while confirmed cases are dropping [4], there may yet be a resurgence of cases once movement restrictions are eased [5]. As such, there is a lot of uncertainty in my probability estimates. [1] https://www.britishairways.com/en-us/destinations/far-east-and-australia/china

To be consistent with my answers to this challenge as I think the data tells us, the outbreak is tapering off. If so, for BA it will be no justification not to resume flights after April 17.
